As William Richardson, executive vice-president and provost of Pennsylvania State
University, prepares to assume
the office of president of Hopkins
on July 1, he ushers in a new Era
of Good Feeling for the University. Widely regarded at Penn
State as a team player and consensus builder, Richardson, a
public health administration expert trained in business, succeeds
retiring president Steven Muller
as the eleventh president of Johns
Hopkins and follows Milton
Eisenhower as the second
Hopkins president to come from

Penn State. The Board of
Trustees approved Richardson's
nomination two weeks ago on
January 17.
The other contender for the
presidency, Massachusetts Institute of Technology provost
John Deutch, withdrew from consideration for the office after
objections were raised to his candidacy. Deutch's withdrawal left
Richardson as the sole candidate
whose name was submitted to the
Board of Trustees.

appointment, Richardson described his management style as one

Muller reflects on 18 years at Hopkins
MULLER, from 1
about recently and that I know the
Student Council here has had on
its agenda, as the undergraduate
body here increases [as] the FiveYear Plan calls for, I think that
raises questions about the extracurricular impact of having an
increased
number
of
undergraduates both in _Engineering and Arts and Sciences in
terms of housing, facilities, space
for various student activities, and
so on. And the parallel question
of the academic environment: the
size of the faculty, the quality of
the program, and so on, and I'm
sure that he wants to address
those. He really has no alternative
but to do that. . . . I am sure the
question of the quality of the curriculum will be brought to his attention by students, both graduate
and undergraduate, if not by
faculty and deal's.
N-L: Penn State is a land grant
nstitution; community and state
-elations are paramount. Do you
corsee any difficulties for Dr.
Richardson adjusting to the new
mvironment at Hopkins?
SM: The direct answer to your
iuesiton is no. . . . First and most
important, there really isn't any
other place like Johns Hopkins,
and I do think that there is a
challenge in getting to know and
understand and get a feeling for
Hopkins. I think he knows that
perfectly well, and I think he
doesn't need any special advice,
but obviously he is going to make
the same effort any new president
would make to get to know this
place and understand it. . . . The
reason that I say no to your question is because I think the
experience he's had as provost at
Penn State was, I'm sure, very
useful. . . . There are aspects of
the Penn State experience that
are, in fact, very relevant. Penn
State has become a system; it isn't
just a college. I think they have
over 20 branches or campuses.
And that will help him with the
geographic and administrative
decentralization of Johns
Hopkins. Also, in terms of governance, while the regents at Penn
State are chosen in a different
way than the trustees are here,
once they are there, the relationships with the board tend to be
largely the same whether the institution is private or public. The
main thing is he has extensive experience in research universities
and that's essential. . . I think the
transition to Hopkins is always an
adventure for anybody because
Hopkins is a special place.

N-L: Considering that Hopkins is
a prominent university, located in
a city with one of the nation's
largest black populations, how do
l'ou account for the lack of any
Afro-American studies at
Hopkins?
SM: Well, I think you have to
sort of think about the context in
which Hopkins is located and
operates. I can't say that
everything we have done is right,
but I think as you ask that question one has to think about the
relationship of Hopkins to an institution such as Morgan State
University, to the other
predominantly black institutions,
in the area. . . and also to the
overall situation in the city and
region. My own feeling is that
Hopkins over time can and should
do more with Morgan. I am
really
pleased that we got this collaborative program in space
research which is shared with
Morgan, and if we can begin to
work that out we can strengthen
our relationship with Morgan in
fields such as engineering. . .
We've also made an effort to
increase minority enrollment,
particularly black enrollment, and
I think we've got to continue that.
I think you could ask why
Hopkins doesn't have an art
department, and the reason is that
there is the Maryland Institute
College of Art; we don't have a
music department because
Peabody is there. And I don't
think we could do as good a job
of Afro-American studies department as Morgan can do.
The following question comes
from the Women's Center. The
report submitted by the Human
Climate Task Force referred to
problems experienced at this
university by womeei and
minorities that were unique and
exceptionally acute. How is the
administration addressing the
human climate issue, and why
haven't the steps taken reached
the level of the students.
SM: Well, we've taken that
report very seriously land] given
it a lot of attention, but there are
certain priorities that we can address as a central administration
and the biggest focus has been the
question of day care. . . . That's
an example of where we have immediately given a priority and
where the central administration
has a real voice. . . . The question
of how we reach student levels is
one that at Hopkins really has not
been a province of the central
administration, the central administration doesn't have students

and that's, at Hopkins, a question
for the divisions. If a report is
made that points to problems at
Hopkins, and that report is supported by and sponsored by the
central administration, then in
order for it to be effective it has
to be digested and addressed in
the divisions. That's the best and
only way this place can really
work. And that takes time. . . .
N-L: You stated last year that you
were planning to devote your remaining time to raising money to
increase Arts and Sciences 's endowment. What progress has
been made?
SM: Well, that turns out to be at
this point a more embarrasing
question than I would like. In this
sense, first, if you look at annual
giving to Arts and Sciences and
overall giving, there have really
been wonderful increases. I think
the annual giving in Arts and
Sciences ahs gone up 50 percent.
Those are mostly small gifts, so
the dollars are not overwhelming,
but the 50 percent increase in any
year is a very desirable thing
because usually the problem is
not to hold levels of support but
to increase them. The overall giving to Arts and Sciencetwent up
last year something like 20 percent. That's larger dollars and not
part of the annual giving program
as such, but that's also a very
welcome development.
The reason I say that it's a
little embarrassing for me to go
further is because the trustees
have decided that they're in effect going to sponsor an effort to
get some gifts more or less as a
tribute to me and they asked me
if they did that, where would I
like that money to be directed and
I have asked them and they've
agreed that such funds should be
an endowment for Arts and
Sciences. But, obviously, I'm not
engaged in raising money as a
tribute to me; other people are
doing that.
N-L: How do you accountfor the
relative decline of the MSE as a
competitive research library at a
university which characterizes
itself as one of the nation's
premier research institutes?
SM: The problem that you allude
to is a problem that is not exactly unique to the MSE. What we
are looking at is that there has
been an explosion for the past 30
or 40 years in publications in the
form of journals, and the
librarians call that serials. The
cost of these journals is rising
much, much faster than the consumer price index, particularly at
a world-class university where so

many of the journals are printed
abroad. The dollar has declined
by about half in the past five years
against, for example, the German
mark, the Japanese yen. . . . We
are paying a fortune for foreign
serials compared to American
ones
Plus shelving all that
stuff is increasingly a problem. It
takes enormous amounts of space
and all the libraries are either going to compact shelving, which is
new equipment and costs money.
We're doing that in the basement
of the New Engineering Building
and pushing for increases in
space. The only way to deal with
[the problem] is through [library]
consortia. The library does
belong to two major consortia and
it's just going to be the case that
no single library, even the .
highest-quality libraries, are going to be able to continue to
support all journals and acquire
them.
N-L: What are your plansfor next
year?
SM: What I can tell is that I've
been in a job for two decades,
ever since 1971, where I have had
very little discretion as to how I
spend my time. I feel very blessed because instead if having died
or gotten sick in this job, the prospect is that I will walk out. . .
still feeling very vigorous and
very good and, as far as I know,
healthy. That means that my first
priority is to make the most of ths
privilege of having discretion as
to what I do. What I would like
to do is to keep very busy,
because I have no intention of
retiring in the sense of doing
nothing or doing less. I think that
would drive me crazy; it would
probably kill me. But I'm going
to be doing a variety of things that
I want to do. A few because I've
been asked to do them, and a few
that I really want to do. I do want
to write a book. I know that I will
be doing some consulting and
there is one major, not full-time,
but one major activity that I probably will be engaged in. . . [but]
I'm really not free to go into
detail. Something that people
sometimes forget is that I didn't
start out in life with the intention
of becoming a university president. I started out with the intention of becoming a professor and
I became one, and in some ways
I was not so bad at that. . . . I
would like to plan over a longer
period than next year or even the
year after to go back to teaching
either on a part-time or full-time
basis. I can tell you, I am really
looking forward to all this. I am
making some plans, but I can't
give you a simple ,answer.

ROTC honor awarded
by Chris VandeKieft
Scot Tebo, a Hopkins senior,
has been named Cadet Battalion
Commander of the Johns
Hopkins University Army ROTC
Battalion for the Spring 1990
semester.
As Cadet Battalion Commander, Tebo will work closely
with the Hopkins ROTC cadre in
supervising the training and activities of the 81-person battalion,
which is comprised of students
from Hopkins, UMBC, the
University of Baltimore, and the
University of Maryland at College Park and at Baltimore. The
battalion currently has scheduled
two weekend field training exercises (FTX),. a military ball in

April, and weekly classes.
"I'm eager to start working
with Scot," said fellow cadet
Mark Bateman. "I have no doubt
that the battalion will have an excellent spring."
Tebo, a Distinguished Military
Student, has served on the battalion's Color Guard, and is a
1989 graduate of the U.S. Army
Airborne School. This past summer he successfully completed
ROTC Advanced Camp, the sixweek training program for cadets
at Fort Bragg, NC.
"I feel very positive about the
upcoming semester," Tebo said.
"We have a good foundation to
build on from the first semester,
and I hope we will be able to improve on that."

Walter Mosely, president of
the Black Caucus at Penn State,
said that, under Richardson, ties
between the caucus and university officials have increased.
"I've never met with Richardson personally although I have
met with the vice-provosts," he
said. He added that, although
issues such as inadequate minority representation on the student
council remain unresolved, "the
administration has sincerely tried
to work out the problems."
"Richardson thinks diversity

Richardson's tenure, Penn State
increased financial aid to its
minority students. The university has also developed close ties
with two local black colleges,
Lincoln and Chaney Universities.
This involvement allows for
faculty exchanges and special
consideration for student transfers

to Penn State.
Martin was uniformly positive
about Richardson, except when
questioned about the condition of
the Arts and Sciences at Penn
State.
"Four or five years ago a decision was made about the
engineering program," Martin
said. Penn State expanded the
engineering school at the expense
of Arts and Sciences, as well as
the architecture program, he said.
"It's hard to say whether
Richardson or [Penn State President] Jordan were responsible,"
he said.
Martin hastened to add.
however, that the Planning and
Budget Advisory Committee had
come to the conclusion this past
fall that there was "a great need"
for improvements in the Arts and
Sciences. Richardson supported

that a food court "will take away

plan," said Schuerholz, "We
don't know exactly when we'll do
it." In the first stage of the master
plan, which could accompany the
completion of McCoy in 1992,

-34th Street and make it into a

neighborhood. We could have a
real student housing complex, a
student center." Such a center

APL tests missiles
by Steven Mizrach

The Johns Hopkins Applied
Physics Laboratory has been involved in extensive testing for the
Trident II submarine-launched
missile system for the Navy. Recent tests have been moderately
successful, and the Navy has
stepped up production; however,
there were several spectacular
failures last summer. APL is
under contract to evaluate and test
the Trident II missile system. According to local peace activist
Max Obuziewski, "Every black
box containing all the trajectory
information on the Trident submarine is sent back to the APL
to be studied by the scientists
there."
As of 1987, the APL had three
separate Trident contracts with
the Navy: Strategic Weapons
System Evaluation, $4.9 million;
Sonar, Command, and Control
System Evaluation, $12.5

million; Trident I Backfit System
Evaluation, $12.3 million. The
first program's parameters are
described as covering "the
Navy's operational tests and
evaluation of the Trident II
system, and it addresses all
aspects of system performance
except accuracy, which is
evaluated in another program,
and supporting the Navy in this
area APL generates data requirements, test plans and
analyses. Then it assesses performance on the data so acquired.
According to another local
peace activist, Pat Birnie, "The
Trident is clearly a first-strike
weapon, and its only purpose
would be to pre-empt retaliation,
that is, to unilaterally destroy the
enemy. And APL makes sure that
the Trident is that much more
lethal." Many experts believe
that "first-strike" nuclear
weapons are highly destabilizing,
especially now that Soviet

military response is so
unpredictable.
The Applied Physics Lab is
compelled to carry on these tasks.
According to Nuclear Free
America director Albert Donnay.
"The contract with the Navy is
such that if the lab refuses their
research requests they may
assume control of it—that's their
guarantee, that they can buy out
the lab. The best that Hopkins can
do is divest and let the Navy solely find researchers for their programs. But the nuclear weapons
work will go on." Many opposition groups, including the APL
Conversion Project, have come to
accept this, but still maintain that
"it is not right for one of the nation's leading health care research
institutes to do such terrible
military projects for the Department of Defense."

Many people, reading the cartoon on page nine of the
Hopkins Spectator (presumably our campus' counterpart
to the Dartmouth Review), may have mistakenly assumed that the artist's slam on the alleged shortcomings of
Hopkins' female students was simply another expression
insecure male misogyny. Yet to do so would be to
misunderstand a subtle effort on the part of the Spectator
to draw our attention to serious shortcomings within the
university.
In the first panel of the strip, in which the cartoonist
refers to Hopkins women as dogs, he is clearly trying to
convey, in the verbal shorthand so prevalent here (orgo,
chem, 'Sems, etc.) that females at this institution are
UNDERdogs. For this cour-ageous stand he should be
commended by all. Not even the administration is willing
to admit that the climate for women here can be so
notoriously uncomfortable as to actually discourage them
from pursuing faculty positions.
The complex "2x + 1"rule, laid out so cleverly in the
two boxes which follow the first, is self-evidently a twopronged strike at the underrepresentation of women on the
math and science faculty, and a critique of the University's misleading policy of OVER-representing women in
glossy brochures promoting the school to the outside
world. The charge that there may be a mathematical formula behind the latter practice is both astonishingly bold
and frightening in its implications. The last block of the
cartoon, in which it is noted that "a little math and imagination goes a long way," is a skillful blending of these
two concepts. Not content to allow the strip to stop at this
already impressive conclusion, however, the character in
this sentence manages to mangle his grammar in a way
that would make a fourth-grade teacher cringe, thereby
condemning the inadequacies of the American educational
system.
To be fair, however, the News-Letter must confess to
not having an altogether clean record when it comes to
,promoting tolerance on campus, despite our aspirations

to that end. Several times in the recent past, we published
staff work which should not have been printed due to its
intolerant, demeaning characterizations of Hopkins
students. At the time we published them, we accepted an
argument that not to do so would be tantamount to censoring a point of view with which we did not agree. After
reflection, we realized that nothing could be further from
the truth, and at the end of last term refused to run yet
another example of terminal intolerance.
Our response to a charge of censorship is that all internal productions are subject to the same editorial
prerogatives that apply to anything else produced by the
News-Letter staff. To deny the editorial board the right
to decide which internal productions are appropriate, and
which are not appropriate, for inclusion in the News-Letter,
is to make our jobs superfluous. At the same time, we do
not edit outside contributions such as letters to the editor,
or Speaker's Corner contributions, for content. The
distinction between editorship, the supervision of the internal policies or production of a publication, and censorship, by which we would refuse to publish anything we
didn't like, is an important one. The sheer number of letters to the editor we print each week, often unfavorable
to us, attests to the fact that we do not presume to censor
the Homewood campus, and that people realize this to be
the case.
Sexism and racism have no place on our campus, or in
the News-Letter. Although we, of course, have no control
over letters to the editor and the like, nor would we want
such control, the News-Letter reserves the right to edit the
internal productions of our own newspaper as we see fit.
To do so is not to censor, but to be responsible editors.
If we have failed to live up to this responsibility as fully
as we should have in the past, we apologize. We can only
hope that other publications will learn from our mistakes
as we have, and endeavor to make Johns Hopkins the haven
from prejudice, and its stablemate, ignorance, that this
University should be.

organization that seeks to foster
silence. It is for this, all well as
for other reasons, that I am
hereby officially resigning from
my position as Business Manager
of the News-Letter.

This week, in our mailboxes,
the Johns Hopkins Women's
Center asks us if we are prepared
to tolerate a sexist cartoon in a
University-sponsored political
journal. Since our tuition money
helps support the "Spectator,"
and since our university sponsors
it, we should have a say in what
types of material are inappropriate and offensive. The
Women's Center would like the
administration to make it clear to
the "Spectator" (and other
university-supported publications) that sexism (and racism,
anti-Semitism, homophobia, etc.)
will not be tolerated within their
pages. linot, the administration
at least tacitly supports such incidents of prejudice.
Mr.
while
However,
Podurgiel's cartoon is as offensive as it is childish, it must not
be viewed as an isolated incident
that might be shrugged off as an
aberration. The "2x +1" cartoon
is not the first published prejudice
at Hopkins, and unless we can
create a fundamental change in
our campus atmosphere it will
hardly be the last.
Let me begin with some
history. During my first year at
Hopkins. I heard occasional
rumors about a legendary TEP
fraternity newsletter. Reports
varied—it was sexist, it wasn't
really that bad, it was funny, it
was awful. and, most commonly, it wouldn't have come to
anything if it hadn't been found
by a man-hating radical feminist
who just wanted to stir things up
and happened to share a Gilman
box with a TEP brother.
When I agreed to write this
editorial, I was told that the
Women's Center had some copies
of the newsletter, so I decided to
read it to find out once and for
all. No two ways about it, it's
repulsive. It depicts the brutal
double-rape of a woman and her
mother. complete with threats,
force, and violence. The narrator
asks, "don't you know anything
about love you rotten slut?" and
calls his younger victim "you
filthy whore." The mother is
called "you rotten old stank
box." The narrator calls the rape
a "romantic encounter," and
claims he left his date and her

mother "in rapture."
Nor does the newsletter stop
there. It also notes that Reagan
and Mondale both have "a BUSH
for a running mate." Reference
is also made to "Marty's bitch,"
and (in a brother-identification
quiz) to the adjective "bitchless."
Nor has the Hopkins NewsLetter been exempt from prejudice under the guise of humor.
In last year's April Fools jokeissue of the "News-Litter," some
Campus Nots were sexist, racist,
and homophobic. One referred to
the Chinese Students Association
as "Little. Yellow. Different."
Another referred to a group that
would kidnap a good-looking IR
major and clone her, turning the
clone over to a Hopkins male.
This was to solve the "problem"
that Hopkins "girls" don't look
like girls. Finally, another "Not"
implied that someone who was
gay or lesbian didn't know
whether they were a man or a
woman. And the year before that,
we had the infamous "Gouchercondom" strip of "With Eyes
Closed."
Prejudice is not limited to
Hopkins publications. Rather, it
pervades our entire campus.
Although at least 10 percent of
Hopkins students are homosexual, Gay and Lesbian Alliance
posters are constantly torn down,
generally within a day of being
put up. Homophobia is so bad on
this campus that GALA officers
publically
have
become
anonymous to avoid harassment.
In lists distributed to all students,
listing the various SAC groups
and their officers. GALA gives
only a number which interested
students can call. (Perhaps this is
a good time to introduce myself
as GALA's newest vicepresident.)
Furthermore, while some incidents can be chalked up to ignorance, or general hostility,
some are so premeditated as to be
nothing less than deliberate social
violence. One example is the
poster for the fictitious "Goucher
Get Laid Party" which was placed on the door of the Women's
Center. Since last year's Center
was hidden in the basement of
AMR II, this took a bit of effort.
The "Spectator's" "2x + 1" car-

toon is the most recent example.
At the end of his cartoon, Mr.
Podurgiel requests hate mail.
Thus, he knew that his cartoon
would upset a large portion of the
Hopkins community—indeed, he
planned it. Well, Mr. Podurgiel,
this isn't hate mail. What I feel
for you is merely pity.
Martin Luther King, Jr. said
that his generation would have to
account not only for the terrible
deeds of the evil few, but also for
the appalling passivity of the good
majority. The same is perhaps
even more true for our own
generation. In every party I've
gone to since I came to Hopkins
I've heard sexist and homophobic
comments, and I suspect you
have too. Every time you see or
hear prejudice and do nothing you
give your tacit approval, just as
the university will if it tolerates
the "Spectator"'s cartoon. Every
time you tell a racist, sexist, or

homophobic joke, you add to the
level of intolerance. In effect, you
say you are proud to live in a
community in which gays must be
closeted, in which women and
minorities are anonymous, and
where prejudice is embraced as
a friend.
The problem here at Hopkins
is indeed large, but it can be solved if we all actively examine and
reform our beliefs, attitudes, and
behavior. We all have prejudices
built up in us—fight yours, and
when others exercise theirs make
it clear you don't approve. Go to
meetings of the Women's Center,
GALA, the BSU, the JSA, and
learn that there's precious little
there to hate or fear. We are the
good majority, but we are passive
and have much to answer for.
Let's begin now.

waiting there when I got back. I
looked over to the doors to the access arm, and they were closed
and locked. There was no flight
attendant at the. podium checking
flight passes. And as I got closer
to the large picture window on the
wall, I noticed that the access arm
was being pulled away from the •
plane.
I dropped my bags.
I said, "Oh, God."
My friend began snickering.
I said, "Oh, God," again.
I began running alongside the
picture window screaming "Oh,
God" in a hysterical screech, and
jumping up and down waving my
arms frantically looking for
attention.
"Hey." I yelled stupidly, as if
the people in the plane would hear
me through the window glass,
over the roar of various engines,
and through airplane walls thick
enough to withstand pressure that
can suck the contacts out of your
face in less than a second.
And then a miracle happened.
The pilot looked up from
whatever he was doing, and saw
me flailing my limbs wildly in the
airport window. He squinted to
make sure it wasn't just the setting sun dancing off his reflective

sunglasses (how would I know,
right?). He pointed at me then
back at the plane.
I stopped jumping. I nodded
my head with much enthusiasm.
He put up a hand, palm out,
and nodded tersely. Then he
opened up the cockpit window
and shouted something to the access arm driver that I couldn't
hear. hut which must have been
something like, "Hey, stop,
some bonehead forgot to get on."
I grabbed my bags again, and
raced to the door, breathing
anxiously.
An ogre who looked surprisingly like the nicest flight attendant I had ever met appeared and
opened the door.
"I am so sorry," I said. My
voice dripped with pathos.
You're beyond sorry," said the
ogre. His voice was like the
house's voice in "The Amityville
Horror." "We should have left
without you."
I was situated on the plane. I
stowed my baggage, fastened my
seatbelt, and prepared myself for
the Flight Attendants' Safety
Mime Hour, a contented grin onmy face, and, as one flight attendant hurried to make her cue, she
leaned over to me and said, "The
captain said to tell you that you
owe him one."

to bring freshmen into contact

Ray Boston's alcohol-free beach
party in the Glass Pavilion.
Hoppy Hour's organizers were
prepared for a huge turnout. In
the social lounge to the left of the
lobby in AMR I was a spread of
chips, vegetables, dip, and
crackers, the food that most people would say constitutes a good
Hoppy Hour in the Glass
Pavilion. But in the social lounge
to the right, heated-serving trays
with chicken fingers and potato
skins were set up on a long table,
along the back of the room was
the usual "bar," and a band
played in a corner.
According to Andrea Perry,
Director of Residential Life,"we

wanted to have it [Hoppy HoUrl
on freshman turf, someplace that
was less intimidating. And we
knew we wanted to have a place
for conversation and music.
Holding Hoppy Hour in the
freshman dorms did attract a
number of students who had
never been to the social before.
Freshman Kyle Gliatto is one of
the newcomers.
"Actually, I wasn't planning
on coming. I saw something was
up and I just wandered in," said
Kyle. "I'll have to come back
some time. It's really good."
According to freshman Richard
Schwartz, many of his classmates
were under the impression that
Hoppy Hour cost money, or that
they would get carded there.
"Having it here might attract
more students, but I like the Glass
Pavilion better. At the Glass
Pavilion it was great with the
bands," said Richard.
Although there were a number
of freshmen in attendance at
various times, they were always

far outnumbered by the up,
perclassmen who showed up.
This could partly be attributed to
the special dinner in the Terrace
Room, partly to the lack of
knowledge about Hoppy Hour.
So why did so many upperclassmen make the trek to the
dorms? The food was not advertised in the Hopkins Halftime
flyer, so there must have been
some other reason.

as a freshman activity,'' said

event was scheduled to end and
long after the hot food was gone,
students still filled the social

On Friday, January 19, hundreds of people crowded the
church in downtown Baltimore at
which one of the world's greatest
authors lies buried. They came to
pay homage to Edgar Allan Poe
on his birthday.
Every year people assemble at
the church for readings and
dramatizations of Poe's work,
and to see a piece of Poe's coffin
and a lock of his hair. The evening is completed with a reading
of The Raven, complete with
champagne and a red rose, at the
grave of the master of the dark
arts.

To all Johns Hopkins University Undergraduates:
On behalf of the HOP, I would like to welcome everyone back from break and hope you all had a good
time. This past semester the HOP went through a period of transition in which we were no longer just throwing out events to you, which you didn't want in the first place. We had a committed team of students who
were finding out what you wanted to see take place at Hopkins and then we did just that. With a firm commitment for a better quality of programming at Hopkins, the HOP Exec Board gave you numerous events last
semester, under its subcommittees, either as a sponsor or co-sponsor as listed below:

—Hoppy Hours of which some of our cosponsors were the Alumni Association,

Some of these events were more successful than others. The Beach Party, which we co-sponsored with Orientation '89, two weeks ago, was a great party that everyone enjoyed. These events can continue to happen, but
we need your help. Our new office is centrally located at the Student Activities Lounge in Levering Hall. Come
on by and join one of our committees, or come to a HOP Exec Meeting and give us some input. We want to
hear from you so we can give us a call, leave a message and we'll get back to you as soon as we can.

1989 at the Movies:
Strong Performances,
Fewer Shootings, and
Touching Moments
by Mark Friedman
It was a kinder and gentler 1989 at the movie
theaters. There were no good protests like those
spawned by "The Last Temptation of Christ" in
1988 and, overall, fewer shootings at Eddie Murphy films—at least in the audience. On screen it
was mayhem as usual, and millions of Americans
trooped off to their local movieplexes to see the
latest and greatest in cinematic fodder.
Yet for all of the obligatory half-baked ideas,
superstar mismatches, and just plain crummy
films, the year brought some memorable performances and moving moments: Michelle Pfeiffer
molding her curves to the piano in "The Fabulous
Baker Boys" and Jessica Tandy taking tiny bites
of pumpkin pie from Morgan Freeman in "Driving Miss Daisy," for example. There was the
painfully graphic, as well, like Mel Gibson
dislocating his shoulder underwater in "Lethal
Weapon 2" and Tom Cruise squirming in his own
excrement in "Born on the Fourth of July."
Top Ten lists are commonplace among critics
of all kinds. But how many critics can say that
their Top Ten of 1989 will first be published in
February? I'm a step ahead of the Oscar nominations (I can only vote for technical awards) but
way behind almost everyone else. I offer a special
merit award to "Roger and Me" for compiling
the longest list of Top Ten citations in memory.
My balloting officially ended last Saturday, and
after some furious lobbying by Tom Hanks for
his role in "Turner and Hooch," I've made my
decisions. Unfortunately, I was forced to disqualify "In Country" because my objectivity was
somewhat skewed by an experience at the screen-

ing: A member of the audience approached me afterwards and asked if I had been
in the film.

Following are Mark Friedman's Top Ten Films
of 1989:
1 ."Glory" An improbable piece of history is
bronzed for posterity by Edward Zwick (coexecutive producer of "thirtysomething") and a

stellar cast, led by Denzel Washington and
Morgan Freeman. Triumphant, haunting, and profoundly affecting, the actors in "Glory" give the
story of the 54th Massachusetts regiment (the first
all-black volunteer unit in U.S. History) an urgency that drives the film and leaves a monument to

a group of men who were martyrs for more than
one important cause. The best of the best.
2."Crimes and Misdemeanors" Woody
Allen's nineteenth film in many ways is his richest
and most satisfyingly complex. Glowingly filmed, "Crimes and Misdemeanors" deftly intertwines stories of major and minor moral transgressions. The themes of lust and redemption lock
neatly into the end of the 1980s, a decade Allen
clearly identifies with our inability (or lack of
desire) to see how bad we really are.
3."Do the Right Thing" Spike Lee builds a
neighborhood and an unforgettable line-up from
a blistering summer's day, the belligerent thump
of Public Enemy, and pent-up doses of
unacknowledged hostility. Lee's imagery and
ideas challenge moviegoers (and the status quo)
with a boldness unique among popular filmmakers
today.
4."Driving Miss Daisy" Jessica Tandy and
Morgan Freeman give the best leading performances of the year in this tender story of a twentyfive year relationship between an incorrigible
Jewish widow and her black chauffeur in the
South. There's enough sass on both sides to keep
the schmaltz potential at bay, and the ending is
genuinely poignant.

TIBET: HEALING, MUSIC AND DANCE
Since 1959, the monks of the Ganden Shartse Monastery
have attempted to remake their lives in exile in India.
During this time, the monks have continued their
traditional ceremonies associated with Medicine Buddha
Tantras and related practices. They are specifically
performed to promote physical and spiritual health in the
individual and the environment. Their presentation
includes explanations in English by Cheme Tsering, the
organizer of the tour.
These rituals, which are performed regularly at Ganden
Shartse, are being presented for the first time in the
West. A $10 donation is request, with courtesy tickets
available for Johns Hopkins students through the
Office of the Chaplain. The funds will be used to develop
a new school of Tibetan Buddhism for monks in exile.

The records listed below were judged by the
News-Letter music staff as the best of 1989. Each
of the four critics was asked to submit a list of
ten favorite albums and ten favorite songs, with
the stipulation that none of the songs could be from
any of the listed albums. The result is predictably
eccentric—removed from the Top 40 mainstream
in most cases, but not especially radical.
Several of the critics complained that they
couldn't produce a list of the ten "best" records,
offering instead eight, eleven, or a group of ten
that included a reissue or a record released late
in 1988. These deviant choices have been preserved. More complaints came about choosing
songs—"there are just too many, man"—and
those selections are admittedly more arbitrary than
the album choices.
In keeping with the democratic spirit of the
enterprise, the lists were compiled in a random
order, with songs (in quotes) and albums (italics)
mixed together. Each critic contributed at least one
description of a favorite release; these are interspersed throughout the list. Titles that appeared
on more than one list appear below only once.
There were several records for which the NewsLetter could not find enough information to print;
these were omitted from the final list.
In the end, there are no "No. 1" or "No. 2"
records here. What remains instead is a warped,
thoii,,h decidedly agreeable, version of the album
and single Top 40's of 1989.

Seiler's stops using foam
by Beth Jones
Recently Seiler's cafeterias on
campus began phasing out their
use of polystyrene foam because
of its effect on the environment.
Over the last year I've been hearing about people boycotting
polystyrene foam, picketing fast
food restaurants. Cities like Minneapolis/Saint Paul and Berkeley
have banned it. A lot of people
are probably wondering what the
big deal is all about. Last fall I
went on a fact finding mission
about polystyrene foam and this
is what I found out.
Styrofoam is actually a trade
name like Thermos and Q-Tip.
The real name is polystyrene
foam. It is a petroleum product,
so it is using up our dwinkling
supplies of fossil fuels. It is made
by
polymerizing
styrene
monomers in the prosence of
heat. A combination of ethylene
and benzene is often used in the
reaction. Styrene, ethylene and
benzene are all toxic.
Although most polystyrene
foam manufacturers no longer
use CFC's, polystyrene foam still
contributes to ozone depletion.
This is because one of the most
popular alternatives to CFC is
HCFC-22. This compound is less
damaging because it breaks up
more readily in the lower atmosphere before it reaches the
o7one laver. Unfortunately, many
intact molecules still reach the
ozone layer, so HCFC is
estimated to be only 5 percent less
damaging to the ozone layer than
the original CFC
Manufacturing polystyrene
foam is a direct source of smog.
Butane and pentane are the two
other alternatives to CFC's being
by
used
manufacturers
(McDonald's uses pentane). Up
to 50 percent of these chemicals
are released into the atmospere
during manufacture; there they
create cmoc in the form of ozone.
At ground level ozone is a serious
pollutant. In animal studies it has

been linked with lung damage and
decreases in the capacity to fight
infection.
Because it is made of toxins,
polystyrene foam is dangerous to
make. Occupational exposure to
Styrene during manufacture can
cause irritation of the eyes, cracking and itching skin, headaches,
fatigue, lung inflammation and
liver and kidney damage. Cases
of liver damage have been found
in workers employed over five
years. Butane and pentane are
highly explosive and also pose a
saftey threat.
Large quantities of toxic waste
are produced during the manufacture of polystyrene. In fact, according to an EPA ranking of
chemicals produced in the U.S.,
polystyrene generates the fifth
largest amount of hazardous
waste, and its principal ingredients, ethylene and benzene, are
ranked fourth and sixth
respectively.
The problems with polystyrene
foam don't end when you throw
it away. Why not'? Because you
are throwing it away. Baltimore's
landfill is due to be full in 2001.
That's only 11 years from now.
The simplest solution to this proDiem is to stop using
"disposables" like styrofoam and
to use reusable or recyclable
materials instead.
In Baltimore up to 90 percent
of our garbage is burned at the
BRESCO incinerator and the incinerator on Pulaski highway. A
significant proportion of the
material going to our landfill is
the ash form these incinerators.
The Center for Fire Rescarch at
the National Bureau of Standards
has published a list of 57
chemicals produced during normal incineration. Styrene oxide is
a known animal carcinogen,
which results when polystyrene
foam is burned at uneven
temperatures similar to those
found in municipal incinerators.
Styrene oxide is thus likely to
leave the stack
during

incineration.
Industry has announced plans

styrofoam to make such products

in-trays. Because they plan to
recycle only up to one qurter of
the total amount of styrofoam,
this will do little to address
disposal problems and nothing to
reduce the amount of styrofoam

What is Teflon?
Teflon is the trademark name for polytetrafluoroethylene, a
polymer. It was discovered by accident by Roy Plunkett.
Plunkett, a chemist for Du Pont, opened the valve on his tank
of tetrafluoroethylene gas, and nothing came out. He weighed
the tank and found that it weighed what it should if it was full.
Intrigued, he sawed the tank open and found a pile of slippery white dust, which turned out to be polytetrafluoroethylene,
a polymer no one knew how to synthesize. The mysteriously
formed polymer was incredibly inert; neither high heat nor
strong acid would affect it.
Plunkett figured out how to synthesize polytetrafluoroethylene
and an application was quickly found—parts of the first atomic
bombs were made of mixtures of metal and Teflon. Du Pont
has since developed several other applications, including
cookware.

Heartbroken by the Hoyas
Hockey suffers first M-D loss
by Jay Calkins
Baltimore, January 25—
The Johns Hopkins ice hockey
team suffered its first MasonDixon League defeat last week,
when they lost a heartbreaker to
the Georgetown Hoyas 3-2. The
Jays completed their fall semester
season at 5-1 in the league, and
9-3 overall.
The Jays and the Hoyas both
entered the contest unbeaten in
league play, and the battle for
first place lived up to its billing
as it delivered thrills from the
opening face-off. On the opening
play, the Hoya center was at,le to
direct the draw to his
defenseman, who immediately atiempted to hit the left wing
streaking down the boards in an
effort to get beyond the Hopkins
defense. The winger ended up being set up by his teammate as
defenseman Paul Schied had the
winger lined up perfectly. After
violently disposing of the Hoya
forward, Schied gained possession of the puck and passed it to
freshman winger Jason Sprague,
who was wide open behind the
Hoya defense. Sprague unloaded
a slap shot from twenty feet out,
beating the Georgetown goalie on
the lower lefthand side to give the
Jays a 1-0 lead in the first minute
of play.
Despite the fast start, Hopkins
had all it could handle with the
fast and powerful Georgetown
club. The action was fast and
furious, but due to tremendous
defensive play in the first period,
the Blue Jays were able to cling
to a slim 1-0 advantage. Hopkins
goaltender Pierre Chevrier stopped ten shots in the period.
In the second period of play,
the Jays could no longer stave off
the Georgetown onslaught.
Penalties hampered the Blue Jays
and two powerplay goals gave
Georgetown a 2-1 lead. "You
can't afford to play a team like

Georgetown shorthanded," said
coach Steve Wirth. The Jays
played the period very defensively with offensive opportunities
coming few and far between.
"We played like we were intimidated," said Captain Mike
Holmes. "They weren't hitting
that hard, but due to experience
with them in the past years some
of our guys were psyched out
before they even stepped on the
ice. When you slow up just as you
and a player on the other team
meet at the puck that means that
they'll always be making the
play, and we'll always be reacting to it. That's why we were
forced to play so defensively."
The third period was simply a
war in which both teams played
evenly. The Jays could not afford
to play even up, however, since
they trailed by a goal. Despite
some good opportunities,
Hopkins could not break through
with the needed score. With just
over a minute to play the Jays
found themselves playing shorthanded and trailing 2-1. As
Georgetown prepared to pursue
their advantage by entering the
Hopkins zone, Chris Crosby
decided to take a gamble. Crosby
rushed the oncoming forward in
order to force him to pass, but
broke off in the direction of the
nearest Hoya player just as he
saw the pass being made. The
result was a clean interception
and a one-on-one break. The
Hoya defenseman forced Crosby
to the right of the goal, but
somehow Crosby managed to get
off a backhand shot that fooled
the Georgetown goalie. The shot
passed the goalie but hit the post.
Sprague, trailing the play, rushed for the loose puck and got to
it just as the Georgetown goalie
did. The two collided and the
puck came free. Crosby picked
up the loose puck and fired it in,
but as he did so a Georgetown

defender dislodged the net from
its stand. When the goal moves,
the puck is whistled dead, and
therefore the goal was disallowed. The referee declared that the
net had been removed purposely, however, and ruled that a
penalty shot be taken by Hopkins.
Sprague was chosen for the task,
and the freshman displayed his
usual veteran manner as he slipped the puck between the legs of
the Georgetown goalie to even the
score at 2-2 with 1:05 left to play.
Georgetown maintained its
man advantage, however, and
pressed hard in the Hopkins zone.
The two defending forwards for
the Blue Jays got caught high at
center ice, and when one was
beaten, a four-on-two break for
Georgetown resulted. which they
were able to convert into a score.
With just 35 seconds left to play,
the Hoyas took a 3-2 lead that
they would hold.
"I don't know what we have to
do to beat those guys," exclaimed senior assistant Vinny Alfi in
reference to the fact that the Blue
Jays have never beaten the
Hoyas. The return engagement of
the Hopkins-Georgetown matchup will be next semester at
Georgetown. "We'll be ready for
that one, I can promise you,"
said Mike Holmes..
Despite the loss, the stickmen
were pleased with the first half of
their season. "This is by far our
best season," explained Alfi. "If
you would've told me that after
losing the first two lines from last
year's club we'd be 9-3, I would
have said you were nuts." Added Holmes, "Last year everyone
looked to Billy (Marquardt) and
Gibbo (Pat Gibbons) to do
everything, and when they didn't
our team folded. Now everyone
feels like they have to contribute
for us to win, and so we get a
great
team
effort."

Fencers skewer Lafayette and
Haverford in Easton, PA
Courtesy of the Fencing Team
Easton, PA, January 27—
The men's fencing team traveled to Easton, PA, where it continued its successful season with
a two-meet romp of Lafayette and
Haverford. The win against
Lafayette was expected, but the
Haverford team was a bit of an
unknown—a possible contender.
In the end, the Hopkins swordsmen took down both schools
with little trouble. The final
scores were Hopkins 22,
Lafayette 5, and Hopkins 20,
Haverford 7.
The foil team made a fine
showing in both meets, winning
the weapon each time. Co-captain
Michael Greenfield had a 4-1
record for the day, Yen-len Tang
fenced 3-1, and sophomore Rich
Millheiser was 4-1. In addition,
senior Li-Kuo Kong put in a 2-0
showing, and sophomore Matt
Rosin was 2-0. While foil is often
the uncertain link in the Hopkins
fencing chain, the squad seems to
be gaining momentum.
The epee team turned in a solid

performance, going 7-2 in both
meets. Juniors Tim Train and Andrew Donnalley were undefeated
at 5-0 and 4-0, respectively.
Train is undefeated in dual meets
this season. Sophomore Jorge
Gana was 3-2 for the day, fencing well but dropping two close
bouts to Haverford. Jason Coleman was 2-1 and Darren Miller
was 0-1.
The sabre team held its end,
easily defeating Lafayette 8-1 and
edging out Haverford in a much
harder-fought match. Leading the
way was junior Rob "Frito"
McLay, whose 5-0 record included three of the five victories
against Haverford. Having a
more difficult time was senior cocaptain
Andrew "A.J."
Jablonowski, 3-2 on the day, who
lost two of three against Haverford. Junior Pete Kim also
finished the day 3-2, both losses
coming to Haverford. Junior John
O'Connell finished with a record
of 1-1, and junior Juan Suros won
the only bout he fenced.
Coach Dick Oles complimented the squad, "This team

has matured from a group of unsure novices into a poised,
hungry, and well-balanced unit
capable of winning back the
MACFA title which we let slip
through our fingers by one touch
last year. But we need to take
these meets one at a time, and we
can expect the two toughest meets
this weekend to be with Baruch
and William and Mary."
Tomorrow eight schools will
gather at Hopkins for a total of
seventeen meets. Beginning at
10:00 am, the Jays will meet the
University of Virginia, Virginia
Polytechnic Institute, the U.S.
Military Academy, William and
Mary College, and Baruch
College.
The latter two schools promise
to be the toughest competition for
the team, but Hopkins is ready for
the challenge and is looking forward to maintaining its winning
record. The competitions will go
on all day in the fencing room at
the Newton H. White Athletic
Center.

that a food court "will take away

-34th Street and make it into a

fraternity parties.

APL tests missiles
by Steven Mizrach

The Johns Hopkins Applied
Physics Laboratory has been involved in extensive testing for the
Trident II submarine-launched
missile system for the Navy. Recent tests have been moderately
successful, and the Navy has
stepped up production; however,
there were several spectacular
failures last summer. APL is
under contract to evaluate and test
the Trident II missile system. According to local peace activist
Max Obuziewski, "Every black
box containing all the trajectory
information on the Trident submarine is sent back to the APL
to be studied by the scientists
there."
As of 1987, the APL had three
separate Trident contracts with
the Navy: Strategic Weapons
System Evaluation, $4.9 million;
Sonar, Command, and Control
System Evaluation, $12.5

million; Trident I Backfit System
Evaluation, $12.3 million. The
first program's parameters are
described as covering "the
Navy's operational tests and
evaluation of the Trident II
system, and it addresses all
aspects of system performance
except accuracy, which is
evaluated in another program,
and supporting the Navy in this
area APL generates data requirements, test plans and
analyses. Then it assesses performance on the data so acquired.
According to another local
peace activist, Pat Birnie, "The
Trident is clearly a first-strike
weapon, and its only purpose
would be to pre-empt retaliation,
that is, to unilaterally destroy the
enemy. And APL makes sure that
the Trident is that much more
lethal." Many experts believe
that "first-strike" nuclear
weapons are highly destabilizing,
especially now that Soviet

military response is so
unpredictable.
The Applied Physics Lab is
compelled to carry on these tasks.
According to Nuclear Free
America director Albert Donnay.
"The contract with the Navy is
such that if the lab refuses their
research requests they may
assume control of it—that's their
guarantee, that they can buy out
the lab. The best that Hopkins can
do is divest and let the Navy solely find researchers for their programs. But the nuclear weapons
work will go on." Many opposition groups, including the APL
Conversion Project, have come to
accept this, but still maintain that
"it is not right for one of the nation's leading health care research
institutes to do such terrible
military projects for the Department of Defense."

Censorshin and editorshi
Many people, reading the cartoon on page nine of the
Hopkins Spectator (presumably our campus' counterpart
to the Dartmouth Review), may have mistakenly assumed that the artist's slam on the alleged shortcomings of
Hopkins' female students was simply another expression
insecure male misogyny. Yet to do so would be to
misunderstand a subtle effort on the part of the Spectator
to draw our attention to serious shortcomings within the
university.
In the first panel of the strip, in which the cartoonist
refers to Hopkins women as dogs, he is clearly trying to
convey, in the verbal shorthand so prevalent here (orgo,
chem, 'Sems, etc.) that females at this institution are
UNDERdogs. For this cour-ageous stand he should be
commended by all. Not even the administration is willing
to admit that the climate for women here can be so
notoriously uncomfortable as to actually discourage them
from pursuing faculty positions.
The complex "2x + 1"rule, laid out so cleverly in the
two boxes which follow the first, is self-evidently a twopronged strike at the underrepresentation of women on the
math and science faculty, and a critique of the University's misleading policy of OVER-representing women in
glossy brochures promoting the school to the outside
world. The charge that there may be a mathematical formula behind the latter practice is both astonishingly bold
and frightening in its implications. The last block of the
cartoon, in which it is noted that "a little math and imagination goes a long way," is a skillful blending of these
two concepts. Not content to allow the strip to stop at this
already impressive conclusion, however, the character in
this sentence manages to mangle his grammar in a way
that would make a fourth-grade teacher cringe, thereby
condemning the inadequacies of the American educational
system.
To be fair, however, the News-Letter must confess to
not having an altogether clean record when it comes to
,promoting tolerance on campus, despite our aspirations

to that end. Several times in the recent past, we published
staff work which should not have been printed due to its
intolerant, demeaning characterizations of Hopkins
students. At the time we published them, we accepted an
argument that not to do so would be tantamount to censoring a point of view with which we did not agree. After
reflection, we realized that nothing could be further from
the truth, and at the end of last term refused to run yet
another example of terminal intolerance.
Our response to a charge of censorship is that all internal productions are subject to the same editorial
prerogatives that apply to anything else produced by the
News-Letter staff. To deny the editorial board the right
to decide which internal productions are appropriate, and
which are not appropriate, for inclusion in the News-Letter,
is to make our jobs superfluous. At the same time, we do
not edit outside contributions such as letters to the editor,
or Speaker's Corner contributions, for content. The
distinction between editorship, the supervision of the internal policies or production of a publication, and censorship, by which we would refuse to publish anything we
didn't like, is an important one. The sheer number of letters to the editor we print each week, often unfavorable
to us, attests to the fact that we do not presume to censor
the Homewood campus, and that people realize this to be
the case.
Sexism and racism have no place on our campus, or in
the News-Letter. Although we, of course, have no control
over letters to the editor and the like, nor would we want
such control, the News-Letter reserves the right to edit the
internal productions of our own newspaper as we see fit.
To do so is not to censor, but to be responsible editors.
If we have failed to live up to this responsibility as fully
as we should have in the past, we apologize. We can only
hope that other publications will learn from our mistakes
as we have, and endeavor to make Johns Hopkins the haven
from prejudice, and its stablemate, ignorance, that this
University should be.

staged media spectacle, undergraduate students at Penn
State have praised both his visibility and his desire to involve students, both graduates and undergraduates, in the
university's descision making process.
Although Richardson must obviously adhere to the five
year plan and other budgetary constraints, he possesses
an ingrained ideology that emphasizes the academic side
of university life. Under such leadership the News-Letter
hopes that Arts and Sciences will regain its position as the
epicenter of our University's intellectual life.

Letters

Rosen's cartoons have previously appeared. In fact, in the
December 1 issue (just before
they decided not to run the cartoon) the editors wrote a piece entitled "Speak your mind at the
News-Letter." The editors expressed their "aspiration [for the
News-Letter] to be a forum for
this diverse university." In addition, they even set up a new column, a 'speaker's corner,' which
they claimed would "always be
available to any group or individual who desires to verbalize
his or her feelings on any issue."
The editors concluded by proclaiming,"We are, after all, your
student newspaper."
Yet, in light of their decision
not to run James Rosen's cartoon,
one is forced to conclude that the
editors are, quite simply,
hypocrites. How can anyone take
their above claims seriously
when, in the very next issue, they
refuse to print views of one of
their very own staff members.
Surely, James Rosen is an individual who desires to verbalize
his feelings, yet he was not permitted by the editors to do so.
Regardless of the content of
James Rosen's cartoon, or
anyone else's work for that matter, the editors were wrong not
to publish it. First, because they
openly encouraged viewpoints on
the editorial page, and second and

more importantly, because
something quite wonderful could
have happened if they had
published it. Someone might have
written in who had found the cartoon offensive and someone
might have written in who had
not found the cartoon offensive.
Others, in turn, may have stopped to listen, and to think. Imagine, people talking, other people listening, and still more thinking. Doesn't that sound like what
college life is supposed to be all
about? Shouldn't that be the real
goal of a college newspaper, to
foster and encourage and occasionally even incite an exchange
of ideas'?
Today, all I can hear on the
Homewood campus is silence,
and I cannot be part of an
organization that seeks to foster
silence. It is for this, all well as
for other reasons, that I am
hereby officially resigning from
my position as Business Manager
of the News-Letter.
Erica Roth

This week, in our mailboxes,
the Johns Hopkins Women's
Center asks us if we are prepared
to tolerate a sexist cartoon in a

journal. Since our tuition money
helps support the "Spectator,"
and since our university sponsors
it, we should have a say in what
types of material are inappropriate and offensive. The
Women's Center would like the
administration to make it clear to
the "Spectator" (and other
university-supported publications) that sexism (and racism,
anti-Semitism, homophobia, etc.)
will not be tolerated within their
pages. linot, the administration
at least tacitly supports such incidents of prejudice.
Mr.
while
However,
Podurgiel's cartoon is as offensive as it is childish, it must not
be viewed as an isolated incident
that might be shrugged off as an
aberration. The "2x +1" cartoon
is not the first published prejudice
at Hopkins, and unless we can
create a fundamental change in
our campus atmosphere it will
hardly be the last.
Let me begin with some
history. During my first year at
Hopkins. I heard occasional
rumors about a legendary TEP
fraternity newsletter. Reports
varied—it was sexist, it wasn't
really that bad, it was funny, it
was awful. and, most commonly, it wouldn't have come to
anything if it hadn't been found
by a man-hating radical feminist
who just wanted to stir things up
and happened to share a Gilman
box with a TEP brother.
When I agreed to write this
editorial, I was told that the
Women's Center had some copies
of the newsletter, so I decided to
read it to find out once and for
all. No two ways about it, it's
repulsive. It depicts the brutal
double-rape of a woman and her
mother. complete with threats,
force, and violence. The narrator
asks, "don't you know anything
about love you rotten slut?" and
calls his younger victim "you
filthy whore." The mother is
called "you rotten old stank
box." The narrator calls the rape
a "romantic encounter," and
claims he left his date and her

mother "in rapture."
Nor does the newsletter stop
there. It also notes that Reagan
and Mondale both have "a BUSH
for a running mate." Reference
is also made to "Marty's bitch,"
and (in a brother-identification
quiz) to the adjective "bitchless."
Nor has the Hopkins NewsLetter been exempt from prejudice under the guise of humor.
In last year's April Fools jokeissue of the "News-Litter," some
Campus Nots were sexist, racist,
and homophobic. One referred to
the Chinese Students Association
as "Little. Yellow. Different."
Another referred to a group that
would kidnap a good-looking IR
major and clone her, turning the
clone over to a Hopkins male.
This was to solve the "problem"
that Hopkins "girls" don't look
like girls. Finally, another "Not"
implied that someone who was
gay or lesbian didn't know
whether they were a man or a
woman. And the year before that,
we had the infamous "Gouchercondom" strip of "With Eyes
Closed."
Prejudice is not limited to
Hopkins publications. Rather, it
pervades our entire campus.
Although at least 10 percent of
Hopkins students are homosexual, Gay and Lesbian Alliance
posters are constantly torn down,
generally within a day of being
put up. Homophobia is so bad on
this campus that GALA officers
publically
have
become
anonymous to avoid harassment.
In lists distributed to all students,
listing the various SAC groups
and their officers. GALA gives
only a number which interested
students can call. (Perhaps this is
a good time to introduce myself
as GALA's newest vicepresident.)
Furthermore, while some incidents can be chalked up to ignorance, or general hostility,
some are so premeditated as to be
nothing less than deliberate social
violence. One example is the
poster for the fictitious "Goucher
Get Laid Party" which was placed on the door of the Women's
Center. Since last year's Center
was hidden in the basement of
AMR II, this took a bit of effort.
The "Spectator's" "2x + 1" car-

toon is the most recent example.
At the end of his cartoon, Mr.
Podurgiel requests hate mail.
Thus, he knew that his cartoon
would upset a large portion of the
Hopkins community—indeed, he
planned it. Well, Mr. Podurgiel,
this isn't hate mail. What I feel
for you is merely pity.
Martin Luther King, Jr. said
that his generation would have to
account not only for the terrible
deeds of the evil few, but also for
the appalling passivity of the good
majority. The same is perhaps
even more true for our own
generation. In every party I've
gone to since I came to Hopkins
I've heard sexist and homophobic
comments, and I suspect you
have too. Every time you see or
hear prejudice and do nothing you
give your tacit approval, just as
the university will if it tolerates
the "Spectator"'s cartoon. Every
time you tell a racist, sexist, or

homophobic joke, you add to the
level of intolerance. In effect, you
say you are proud to live in a
community in which gays must be
closeted, in which women and
minorities are anonymous, and
where prejudice is embraced as
a friend.
The problem here at Hopkins
is indeed large, but it can be solved if we all actively examine and
reform our beliefs, attitudes, and
behavior. We all have prejudices
built up in us—fight yours, and
when others exercise theirs make
it clear you don't approve. Go to
meetings of the Women's Center,
GALA, the BSU, the JSA, and
learn that there's precious little
there to hate or fear. We are the
good majority, but we are passive
and have much to answer for.
Let's begin now.

PUNCHLINE, from 8
waiting there when I got back. I
looked over to the doors to the access arm, and they were closed
and locked. There was no flight
attendant at the. podium checking
flight passes. And as I got closer
to the large picture window on the
wall, I noticed that the access arm
was being pulled away from the •
plane.
I dropped my bags.
I said, "Oh, God."
My friend began snickering.
I said, "Oh, God," again.
I began running alongside the
picture window screaming "Oh,
God" in a hysterical screech, and
jumping up and down waving my
arms frantically looking for
attention.
"Hey." I yelled stupidly, as if
the people in the plane would hear
me through the window glass,
over the roar of various engines,
and through airplane walls thick
enough to withstand pressure that
can suck the contacts out of your
face in less than a second.
And then a miracle happened.
The pilot looked up from
whatever he was doing, and saw
me flailing my limbs wildly in the
airport window. He squinted to
make sure it wasn't just the setting sun dancing off his reflective

sunglasses (how would I know,
right?). He pointed at me then
back at the plane.
I stopped jumping. I nodded
my head with much enthusiasm.
He put up a hand, palm out,
and nodded tersely. Then he
opened up the cockpit window
and shouted something to the access arm driver that I couldn't
hear. hut which must have been
something like, "Hey, stop,
some bonehead forgot to get on."
I grabbed my bags again, and
raced to the door, breathing
anxiously.
An ogre who looked surprisingly like the nicest flight attendant I had ever met appeared and
opened the door.
"I am so sorry," I said. My
voice dripped with pathos.
You're beyond sorry," said the
ogre. His voice was like the
house's voice in "The Amityville
Horror." "We should have left
without you."
I was situated on the plane. I
stowed my baggage, fastened my
seatbelt, and prepared myself for
the Flight Attendants' Safety
Mime Hour, a contented grin onmy face, and, as one flight attendant hurried to make her cue, she
leaned over to me and said, "The
captain said to tell you that you
owe him one."

Halftime orientation program was
to bring freshmen into contact
with upperclassmen in social

scheduled in the freshman dorms,
and the program concluded with
Ray Boston's alcohol-free beach
party in the Glass Pavilion.
Hoppy Hour's organizers were
prepared for a huge turnout. In
the social lounge to the left of the
lobby in AMR I was a spread of
chips, vegetables, dip, and
crackers, the food that most people would say constitutes a good
Hoppy Hour in the Glass
Pavilion. But in the social lounge
to the right, heated-serving trays
with chicken fingers and potato
skins were set up on a long table,
along the back of the room was
the usual "bar," and a band
played in a corner.
According to Andrea Perry,
Director of Residential Life,"we

wanted to have it [Hoppy HoUrl
on freshman turf, someplace that
was less intimidating. And we
knew we wanted to have a place
for conversation and music.
Holding Hoppy Hour in the
freshman dorms did attract a
number of students who had
never been to the social before.
Freshman Kyle Gliatto is one of
the newcomers.
"Actually, I wasn't planning
on coming. I saw something was
up and I just wandered in," said
Kyle. "I'll have to come back
some time. It's really good."
According to freshman Richard
Schwartz, many of his classmates
were under the impression that
Hoppy Hour cost money, or that
they would get carded there.
"Having it here might attract
more students, but I like the Glass
Pavilion better. At the Glass
Pavilion it was great with the
bands," said Richard.
Although there were a number
of freshmen in attendance at
various times, they were always

far outnumbered by the up,
perclassmen who showed up.
This could partly be attributed to
the special dinner in the Terrace
Room, partly to the lack of
knowledge about Hoppy Hour.
So why did so many upperclassmen make the trek to the
dorms? The food was not advertised in the Hopkins Halftime
flyer, so there must have been
some other reason.
"I never think of Hoppy !-lour
as a freshman activity,'' said
senior Harvey Silkowitz. "But Iwas surprised that there were so
few freshmen at Hoppy Hour la
semester."
The best measure of success is
not the volume of people,
however. By five of seven
o'clock, five minutes before the
event was scheduled to end and
long after the hot food was gone,
students still filled the social
lounges and the band played on.

On Friday, January 19, hundreds of people crowded the
church in downtown Baltimore at
which one of the world's greatest
authors lies buried. They came to
pay homage to Edgar Allan Poe
on his birthday.
Every year people assemble at
the church for readings and
dramatizations of Poe's work,
and to see a piece of Poe's coffin
and a lock of his hair. The evening is completed with a reading
of The Raven, complete with
champagne and a red rose, at the
grave of the master of the dark
arts.

Strong Performances,

by Mark Friedman
It was a kinder and gentler 1989 at the movie
theaters. There were no good protests like those
spawned by "The Last Temptation of Christ" in
1988 and, overall, fewer shootings at Eddie Murphy films—at least in the audience. On screen it
was mayhem as usual, and millions of Americans
trooped off to their local movieplexes to see the
latest and greatest in cinematic fodder.
Yet for all of the obligatory half-baked ideas,
superstar mismatches, and just plain crummy
films, the year brought some memorable performances and moving moments: Michelle Pfeiffer
molding her curves to the piano in "The Fabulous
Baker Boys" and Jessica Tandy taking tiny bites
of pumpkin pie from Morgan Freeman in "Driving Miss Daisy," for example. There was the
painfully graphic, as well, like Mel Gibson
dislocating his shoulder underwater in "Lethal
Weapon 2" and Tom Cruise squirming in his own
excrement in "Born on the Fourth of July."
Top Ten lists are commonplace among critics
of all kinds. But how many critics can say that
their Top Ten of 1989 will first be published in
February? I'm a step ahead of the Oscar nominations (I can only vote for technical awards) but
way behind almost everyone else. I offer a special
merit award to "Roger and Me" for compiling
the longest list of Top Ten citations in memory.
My balloting officially ended last Saturday, and
after some furious lobbying by Tom Hanks for
his role in "Turner and Hooch," I've made my
decisions. Unfortunately, I was forced to disqualify "In Country" because my objectivity was
somewhat skewed by an experience at the screen-

ing: A member of the audience approached me afterwards and asked if I had been
in the film.

a group of men who were martyrs for more than
one important cause. The best of the best.
2."Crimes and Misdemeanors" Woody
Allen's nineteenth film in many ways is his richest
and most satisfyingly complex. Glowingly filmed, "Crimes and Misdemeanors" deftly intertwines stories of major and minor moral transgressions. The themes of lust and redemption lock

have attempted to remake their lives in exile in India.

The records listed below were judged by the
News-Letter music staff as the best of 1989. Each
of the four critics was asked to submit a list of
ten favorite albums and ten favorite songs, with
the stipulation that none of the songs could be from
any of the listed albums. The result is predictably
eccentric—removed from the Top 40 mainstream
in most cases, but not especially radical.
Several of the critics complained that they
couldn't produce a list of the ten "best" records,
offering instead eight, eleven, or a group of ten
that included a reissue or a record released late
in 1988. These deviant choices have been preserved. More complaints came about choosing
songs—"there are just too many, man"—and
those selections are admittedly more arbitrary than
the album choices.
In keeping with the democratic spirit of the
enterprise, the lists were compiled in a random
order, with songs (in quotes) and albums (italics)
mixed together. Each critic contributed at least one
description of a favorite release; these are interspersed throughout the list. Titles that appeared
on more than one list appear below only once.
There were several records for which the NewsLetter could not find enough information to print;
these were omitted from the final list.
In the end, there are no "No. 1" or "No. 2"
records here. What remains instead is a warped,
thoii,,h decidedly agreeable, version of the album
and single Top 40's of 1989.

Seiler's stops using foam
by Beth Jones
Recently Seiler's cafeterias on
campus began phasing out their
use of polystyrene foam because
of its effect on the environment.
Over the last year I've been hearing about people boycotting
polystyrene foam, picketing fast
food restaurants. Cities like Minneapolis/Saint Paul and Berkeley
have banned it. A lot of people
are probably wondering what the
big deal is all about. Last fall I
went on a fact finding mission
about polystyrene foam and this
is what I found out.
Styrofoam is actually a trade
name like Thermos and Q-Tip.
The real name is polystyrene
foam. It is a petroleum product,
so it is using up our dwinkling
supplies of fossil fuels. It is made
by
polymerizing
styrene
monomers in the prosence of
heat. A combination of ethylene
and benzene is often used in the
reaction. Styrene, ethylene and
benzene are all toxic.
Although most polystyrene
foam manufacturers no longer
use CFC's, polystyrene foam still
contributes to ozone depletion.
This is because one of the most
popular alternatives to CFC is
HCFC-22. This compound is less
damaging because it breaks up
more readily in the lower atmosphere before it reaches the
o7one laver. Unfortunately, many
intact molecules still reach the
ozone layer, so HCFC is
estimated to be only 5 percent less
damaging to the ozone layer than
the original CFC
Manufacturing polystyrene
foam is a direct source of smog.
Butane and pentane are the two
other alternatives to CFC's being
by
used
manufacturers
(McDonald's uses pentane). Up
to 50 percent of these chemicals
are released into the atmospere
during manufacture; there they
create cmoc in the form of ozone.
At ground level ozone is a serious
pollutant. In animal studies it has

been linked with lung damage and
decreases in the capacity to fight
infection.
Because it is made of toxins,
polystyrene foam is dangerous to
make. Occupational exposure to
Styrene during manufacture can
cause irritation of the eyes, cracking and itching skin, headaches,
fatigue, lung inflammation and
liver and kidney damage. Cases
of liver damage have been found
in workers employed over five
years. Butane and pentane are
highly explosive and also pose a
saftey threat.
Large quantities of toxic waste
are produced during the manufacture of polystyrene. In fact, according to an EPA ranking of
chemicals produced in the U.S.,
polystyrene generates the fifth
largest amount of hazardous
waste, and its principal ingredients, ethylene and benzene, are
ranked fourth and sixth
respectively.
The problems with polystyrene
foam don't end when you throw
it away. Why not'? Because you
are throwing it away. Baltimore's
landfill is due to be full in 2001.
That's only 11 years from now.
The simplest solution to this proDiem is to stop using
"disposables" like styrofoam and
to use reusable or recyclable

The Center for Fire Rescarch at

a known animal carcinogen,

temperatures similar to those
found in municipal incinerators.
Styrene oxide is thus likely to
leave the stack
during

styrofoam to make such products

in-trays. Because they plan to

this will do little to address
disposal problems and nothing to
reduce the amount of styrofoam

What is Teflon?
Teflon is the trademark name for polytetrafluoroethylene, a
polymer. It was discovered by accident by Roy Plunkett.
Plunkett, a chemist for Du Pont, opened the valve on his tank
of tetrafluoroethylene gas, and nothing came out. He weighed
the tank and found that it weighed what it should if it was full.
Intrigued, he sawed the tank open and found a pile of slippery white dust, which turned out to be polytetrafluoroethylene,
a polymer no one knew how to synthesize. The mysteriously
formed polymer was incredibly inert; neither high heat nor
strong acid would affect it.
Plunkett figured out how to synthesize polytetrafluoroethylene
and an application was quickly found—parts of the first atomic
bombs were made of mixtures of metal and Teflon. Du Pont
has since developed several other applications, including
cookware.
